Award.AwardTitle: Retaining the Math & Science Teachers We Need: High Quality STEM Teachers in High Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase II project at University of California-Santa Cruz is researching math and science teacher retention and attrition in high needs schools so as to better inform strategies to improve the supply and quality of STEM teachers in public schools. Results from the Phase I project demonstrated the insufficiency of academic and pedagogical training alone to ensure teacher retention in underserved schools. Specifically, the initial data suggested that working conditions, and especially hiring and class assignment practices, might be driving Noyce Scholar Teachers out of their schools and even the profession. This project is specifying the enacted policies and practices in the schools and of the teachers that result in the retention of highly qualified teachers in high-needs schools.

The research project is using a nested case design to follow the thirty-two Noyce Scholar Teachers working in three unique districts, from the Phase I project, through the next three years of their teaching. Teachers' career decisions and trajectories are being tracked and examined within the context of their sites of employment. Insight is being obtained on the organizational contexts that attract high-qualified teachers and the strategies and practices that lead to retention beyond the first few years of teaching. The interplay between individual teacher commitment, career trajectory and decision making, with school and district human resource policy and practices, and with school-level working conditions, is being characterized.

This research is informing the local and national Noyce Scholar community about ensuring a stable teacher workforce. The results are being shared with teacher education students to better guide their job search and opportunity selection process. The case study findings are being summarized in a professional handbook for teachers and human resource personnel on strategies that lead to successful navigation of teacher employment selection, placement, and working conditions that ensures teacher retention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Noyce Phase II study explicitly focuses on the retention of high-quality science and mathematics teachers to teach the increasingly diverse student population in California’s schools. Prior research has highlighted the challenge of providing highly-qualified math and science teacher to students in US schools, particularly those who come from historically underserved communities. The current focus on math and science proficiency, the development of more rigorous content standards, and a shortage of math and science teachers has resulted in supply oriented policy remedies. These generally take the form of financial incentive programs that aim to draw more candidates into math and science teaching or recruit more teachers to teach in high-need schools.  While these are important strategies for recruiting teacher candidates, increasing the supply alone will not solve the problem. Attention must also be directed toward retaining math and science teachers.

The study utilizes a comparative embedded case-study design. The participants are 32 teachers spanning the five cohorts that have participated in the UCSC Noyce teacher scholarship program since 2009. This research considers the hiring and job search processes, the organizational contexts in which these teachers work, and teachers’ career trajectories.

Three case study districts provide the organizational context of the study. Phase one research made clear that district and school context matters in terms of math and science teacher retention. Recruiting and preparing highly qualified math and science teachers in their preservice program did not ensure retention in the school site or profession. Organizational processes occurring at the school and district level significantly influenced teachers’ commitments to continue teaching in high-need schools. Furthermore, human resource practices, in general, are understudied in educational research and work that focuses on understanding how practices support (or undermine) teacher retention and workforce stability is sorely needed. This study fills this crucial gap by studying teachers experience in the context of their schools and districts. 

One of the most significant results of the project has been illuminating the way job search and hiring practices of math and science teachers contributes to their attrition or retention from school level employment as well as the teaching profession. The study finds that NSF Noyce funded math and science teaching fellows demonstrate very little discernment when it comes to choosing their first teaching positions. These teachers commonly accept their first job offer and, when this is combined with minimal preview of the school as a workplace, this decision has profound consequences for success. Retention differences exist between teachers who choose their schools with robust information and those with very limited information. Further, how and why teachers choose schools has profound consequences for their professional success, their persistence in high-need schools, and their retention in the profession.

Analysis has also revealed significant differences in how districts recruit and hire teachers, also with profound consequences for retention. Furthermore, our data suggests that schools that have struggled to recruit and retain highly qualified teachers in the past continue to struggle after hiring NOYCE Fellows. In particular, organizational capacity to place, induct, support, and retain teachers is an ongoing issue that affects retention.
